# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Sure, here's a simple solution using the Julia DataFrames package. Note that this function will add the new column to your data frame in place:

```julia
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = Dates.format.(df[1], "yyyyMM") .|> x -> parse(Int,x)
end
```
This function takes a dataframe `df` as input and adds an additional column to it. For each row in the DataFrame, it extracts the year and month from the DateTime column using the `format` function of the Dates module and concatenate them into one string which is then converted back into an integer format.

You can use this function like so:
```julia
df = DataFrames.DataFrame(dt=Dates.Date[Dates.today, Dates.now, Dates.now()])
add_yearmonth(df)
```
The new column `ym` will contain the year and month of each DateTime in the format "yyyyMM", as integers.
